p: Essential oils (EO) have obtained a lot of awareness as practical bioactive products, principally in pesticide terms [ 15, 18, 19]. The acaricidal action of EO is largely unknown, owing to the complexity of the bioactive substances [ 20]. The acaricidal activity of EO in direct contact has been tested and fumigant trials have been conducted [ 21, 22, 23]. Some studies have attempted to determine the mode of action of EO and their constituents on arthropods [ 24, 25]. The acaricidal properties of EOs may result from more than one mode of action due to the diversity of terpenes and terpenoids or other secondary metabolites that were neuro-insecticides or were species-dependent regarding efficacy; those that showed synergistic efficacy when used in combination, with an octopaminergic system, can mediate the insecticidal activity [ 21, 26]
